section.title: Project Properties
section.para: This dialog is accessible by selecting in the menu.

warning.para: The options displayed in or are always the global settings and never the project specific settings.
If you have defined project specific settings here, they will supercede any modifications you make to the global settings and the later will not be taken into account in your project.

section.title: Languages
section.para: You can either enter the source and target languages by hand, or use the drop down menus.
Language codes are used for the , the , the , the , etc.

OmegaT automatically selects the tokenizers corresponding to the source and target languages but you can manually modify the settings. Tokenizers are useful to provide better matches since they each correspond to a specific language.

listitem.para: Sentence-level segmentation splits the source files "paragraphs" into segments based on segmentation rules.
Leave the box unchecked if you prefer not to segment the paragraphs.
By default, segmentation rules are global and apply to all projects.
You can access the global rules with in the menu.

note.para: Changing the segmentation rules settings during a translation does not modify the segments registered in the project translation memory.

Switching from sentence to paragraph segmentation mid-translation may force OmegaT to upgrade old translation memories that did not use sentence segmentation, but not vice versa. However, OmegaT will attempt to create fuzzy matches for paragraphs by combining existing sentence translations.

If you change the segmentation while translating, you will have to reload the project for the new segmentation to take effect. This will split or merge some previously translated segments, which will therefore no longer be considered translated. Nonetheless, their original translation will still be in the project memory.

listitem.para: You can limit the segmentation rules used by the project to that project by either setting local rules with the button, on the right, or by starting OmegaT from the command line. See for details.
If you use local rules, you can still access the global rules, but modifying them will have no effect on your project.

By default, segmentation rules are global and apply to all projects.
Segmentation rules found when you open (with in the menu) are global rules.
Use this button to create local rules specific to your project. Check the Make the segmentation rules project specific box, and adjust the segmentation rules as desired.
The new set of rules will be stored in the file of the folder of the project and will supersede the global segmentation rules.

note.para: To disable local segmentation rules, uncheck the box or remove that file.

If there are non-unique segments in the source documents, checking this option will set the first translated segment as the default translation and automatically use the same target text in the remaining repeated segments.
You can use to assign an alternative translation to segments that require a different translation.
If not checked, all segments can be assigned a different translation.

If checked, no formatting (inline) tags will be displayed in the source segments. This is especially useful when dealing with texts where inline formatting is not particularly useful (e.g., OCRed PDF, or poorly converted .odt or .docx files.)

note.para: The tags are not really removed from the document, but rather stacked at the end of the segment. In most cases, this should not keep the translated file from opening. If you just need to reduce the number of tags, you can use the script. See for details.

By default, post-processing commands are global and are available to all projects. They are defined in .

note.para: For security purposes, project based external commands are disabled by default. You can enable them by checking in the preferences.

section.title: File locations
section.para: An OmegaT translation project consists of a number of resources in separate subfolders, of an omegat.project file that stores the location of all the subfolders and of a project_save.tmx translation memory file that will contain all the translations made while working on that project.

When a new project is created, OmegaT proposes to create a project folder that contains all the resources used in the translation, but that structure is not compulsory. Ressource subfolders can be located anywhere on your machine, including on shared disks.

You can modify the structure of your project by adding or removing files from the subfolders, or even by changing the subfolders the project will use, at will, even during the course of the translation.
The location of all resources is stored in the file of the . See for details.
Click on Exclusions... to define the files or folders that will be ignored by OmegaT. An ignored file or folder:

listitem.para: is not displayed in the pane,
is not taken into account in the window, and
is not copied to the folder when the translated files are created.

section.para: The Exclusion patterns dialog, allows you to add or remove a pattern, or to edit one by double-clicking it, or selecting it and pressing F2. You can use wildcards that follow the Apache ant syntax.
